title: Should student test scores be used to evaluate teachers? - Quora

response.answer_text: Student test scores should never be used to evaluate teachers—ever. They shouldn’t be used in isolation to determine a student’s fate, either. You’re probably thinking, “She doesn’t want accountability.” That’s not the reason. Here are the reasons: We do not know who or what affected the test scores and what those scores mean without doing further layer sof analysis—especially in upper grades where kids have multiple teachers.Most educators aren’t data trained.You can’t look at a score and attribute it to a single teacher or circumstance. That’s not how data works. Unfortunately, that’s how education is misusing data. It’s causing kids and teachers undue stress, and often gives the (untrained) educators using the data incorrect information. Most educators dealing with the new age of data are not data scientists, not even data trained. Heck, I never even took a stat class in school, because “college” tracked kids had to take calculus, not stat or data analysis. If you’re lucky in grad school—as a scientist, social scientist, or mathematician—you’ll get some quantitative data analysis, bell curves, standard deviations, and petri dish numbers that make big data accessible to you. That’s not the norm for most people dealing with high-stakes data in schools today. To correctly use all the data we’re now collecting, you have to know how data works. We have to ask a million more questions, and get those answers, too. Did the kid eat that day?What happened before the test?What teachers did these high/low-score students have LAST year?Is there a bias we can’t spot on this test?Is there a regional or micro-difference in response to a test or question?How does School A/State A handle this type of curriculum?Where and how was the test delivered?What’s the test used for in this space? Do students know?I would love to say I’m responsible for every successful kid I’ve ever taught, but the truth is this—most would’ve done well with or without me. Heck, maybe they all had YOU last year, and you’re the hero, but you just got a bad eval because the guy before you was out half the year. It’s hard to know. More importantly, it’s impossible to know with the legal certainty you need to fire people over this data. Test data can’t tell us why a student is doing well or poorly this year. It can only give us the next questions to ask to get to the information we want. Here are some of the many reasons test data may not indicate student knowledge: Many students fear tests, and no matter what I do, they freeze.Test environments aren’t realistic—When do we ever say, “Be quiet, don’t check your phone, no food, one tab open only, no music or conversation,” in our own work or class? We’re doing old-school testing for a collaborative generation.There are studies that show historically-low performing subgroups of kids do not have achievement gaps on tests if you don’t tell them it’s The Test. If you say, “activity” or “we’re testing out some questions…” they achieve at the same level as their peers.Adults write the questions. Sometimes adults miss the mark, but kids can’t ask for clarification. In class, they can.There are, in fact, bad questions. I’ve seen many in my research areas on practice tests that were outright wrong.Tests are designed to see what kids know and don’t know. When students start seeing the “don’t know” problems, especially in math, they often shut down. In real life, we wouldn’t put those questions on a test.These are all arguments why standardized tests may or may not accurately measure students. Your question was about teacher evaluation. When tests are used as part of evals, teachers become fearful. Many teach to the test. Some even cheat. Teaching to the test gives kids a bad classroom experience. It kills creativity over time. It’s boring. Students ask, “Is it going to be on the test?” and “What do I have to put for the test?” This is lower-level learning. I want school to be something kids look forward to—where they go to learn passions. Right now, increasing numbers are not engaged. Another reason not to use either standardized test scores for teacher evaluations: kids are improperly empowered. I’ve personally experienced and seen students try to influence teacher evaluations in both directions. They know the elements of teacher evaluation. I’ve heard kids say, “We got Mr. So and So fired!” with pride. They misbehaved during observations or did poorly on purpose on the teacher-designed evaluation data because they didn’t like a teacher. Unacceptable. They tried harder for the teachers they liked. They were very open about this. You can’t use uncertain, non-scientific measures for high-stakes purposes. This includes using test data to determine student graduation, too. Here’s how you can use the data: You can use the data as a “formative assessment,” to help you spot trends. You can then look at data and trends, and make some initial predictions about the “whys” and then do a lot of further investigation to look for causality. In mainstream tech, there are companies and PhD data scientists who deal exclusively with data, because identifying correct underlying causes and effects can cost a company millions. Yet in education, we’re use The Test along with some circumstantial background info to say, “You’re fired.” or “You’re the best!” Doing this is about as accurate as playing drunk darts in a bar, blindfolded. Not every evaluator needs to be high-level data trained. Evaluating teachers is a relationship art. You have to be in their classrooms every day, so you feel like part of the fabric. You have to know teachers, students, and the minute-to-minute front line challenges. If you do, you’ll get a much better picture of where your pockets of success truly lie. You won’t get the real answer using test scores.

It would be if all things were equal in the classroom. If every teacher had exactly the same as every other teacher in terms of the ability and motivation of their students it would work. This is not possible and can easily be manipulated to make sure the opposite is true. Let us say there are three teachers teaching the same subject. One is good friends with the principal. He gets the gifted and talented students due to this connection. The other two are split between one teacher the principal is o.k. with and the other he would like to see retire so he can hire another friend of his. The first gets students of random and average ability. The one he would like to see retire now gets the students with IEP’s and learning disabilities. The first gets awards for teaching based on test scores and the third is forced to retire. This type of thing happens in schools more commonly than you think. Evaluating teachers based on test scores is like evaluating dentists based on their patients annual checkup. Too many cavities in a year among their patients and they lose their license. Do you think as professionals dentists would accept this plan? Why are teachers treated any less as professionals?
